questions.text: Dr. Anjali is conducting a research project on the role of societal factors in health outcomes. She discusses with her mentor about the origin of medical sociology to better understand its evolution. Her mentor asks her if she knows who first proposed the concept of medical sociology. Who is credited with first proposing the concept of medical sociology?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Charles McIntyre

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Medical sociology is a specialization within the field of sociology that was first proposed by Charles McIntyre in 1894.
  • • Medical sociology
  • • specialization
  • • field
  • • sociology
  • • Charles McIntyre in 1894.
  • • Medical sociology includes studies of the medical profession , the relationship of medicine to the public , and of the social factors in the aetiology , prevalence , incidence , and interpretation of disease .
  • • Medical sociology
  • • medical profession
  • • relationship
  • • medicine
  • • public
  • • social factors
  • • aetiology
  • • prevalence
  • • incidence
  • • interpretation of disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The concept of medical sociology is proposed by Charles McIntyre in 1894.
  • ➤ medical sociology
  • ➤ Charles McIntyre
  • ➤ 1894.
  • ➤ Ref : Park 26 th ed pg 760
  • ➤ Ref : Park 26 th ed pg 760

questions.text: In sociological terms, there are various kinds of norms and customs that guide behavior within a society. Some of these are particularly stringent and are observed without deviation. Violation of these norms is often met with severe social penalties or consequences. What is the term used to describe these strict customs?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Mores

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Customs are technically divided into “ folkways ” and " mores ".
  • • Customs
  • • divided
  • • folkways
  • • mores
  • • The folkways are the right ways of doing things in what is regarded as the less vital areas of human conduct . (Less stringent customs) The more stringent customs are called “ mores ".
  • • The folkways are the right ways of doing things in what is regarded as the less vital areas of human conduct . (Less stringent customs)
  • • folkways
  • • right ways
  • • less vital areas
  • • human conduct
  • • The more stringent customs are called “ mores ".
  • • more
  • • stringent customs
  • • mores
  • • Norms - These are the accepted behaviors within a society or group . This is a more general term that encompasses both folkways and mores .
  • • Norms
  • • behaviors
  • • society
  • • group
  • • more general term
  • • folkways
  • • mores
  • • Culture is the learned behavior that is socially acquired.
  • • Culture
  • • learned behavior
  • • socially acquired.
  • • Acculturation - Is cultural contact or mixing of two cultures . It can occur through Trade and commerce, Industrialization, Propagation of religion, Education and Conquest.
  • • Acculturation -
  • • cultural contact
  • • two cultures
  • • Trade
  • • commerce, Industrialization, Propagation
  • • religion, Education
  • • Conquest.
  • • Taboos - These are prohibitions against specific actions or behaviors because they are considered extremely offensive or even dangerous . Violating a taboo can often lead to extreme social sanctions or ostracism . Taboos are the most extreme form of mores’ as they forbid a society’s most outrageous practices, such as incest and murder .
  • • Taboos -
  • • specific actions
  • • behaviors
  • • extremely offensive
  • • even dangerous
  • • Violating
  • • extreme social sanctions
  • • ostracism
  • • extreme
  • • mores’
  • • forbid
  • • society’s
  • • outrageous practices,
  • • incest
  • • murder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The concept of mores in sociology , which are strict norms viewed as vital to a society's welfare and moral health . Violating mores often leads to severe social penalties, reflecting their importance in maintaining social order and ethical standards .
  • ➤ mores
  • ➤ sociology
  • ➤ strict norms
  • ➤ society's welfare
  • ➤ moral health
  • ➤ Violating mores
  • ➤ severe social penalties, reflecting
  • ➤ social order
  • ➤ ethical standards
  • ➤ Ref : Park 26 th ed pg 761
  • ➤ Ref : Park 26 th ed pg 761

questions.text: A Psychiatrist is evaluating a 35-year-old patient. Upon conducting an intelligence test, it is found that the patient's mental age is 30 years. Based on this information, what would be the most appropriate conclusion regarding his level of intelligence?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Low normal

Explanation:

  • • Intelligence Quotient : Is a score derived from one of several different standardized tests attempting to measure intelligence
  • • Intelligence Quotient
  • • score
  • • several different standardized tests
  • • measure intelligence
  • • First intelligence tests were developed by: Binet and Simon (1896)
  • • First intelligence tests
  • • Binet and Simon (1896)
  • • Stern’s IQ Test : Originally IQ was calculated for children
  • • IQ Test
  • • IQ
  • • calculated for children
  • • = (30/35) x 100 = 85.5
  • • Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale (WAIS): David Wechsler (1939) published the first intelligence test designed for an adult population ; It was the first IQ test based on Normal/Gaussian distribution.
  • • Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale
  • • David Wechsler (1939)
  • • first intelligence test
  • • adult population
  • • first IQ test
  • • Normal/Gaussian distribution.

  • • mental retardation
  • • IQ levels

questions.text: During a public health conference, a presenter emphasizes the importance of understanding how humans interact with each other and their patterns of behavior, especially in the context of health behaviors. This study is referred to as:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Sociology

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Social Psychology: The emphasis is on understanding the basis of perception, thought, opinion, attitudes , general motivation and learning in individuals and how these vary in human societies and groups.
  • • Option A.
  • • Social Psychology:
  • • perception, thought, opinion, attitudes
  • • general motivation
  • • learning
  • • individuals
  • • vary
  • • human societies
  • • groups.
  • • Option C. Anthropology: Study of the physical, social and cultural history of man. It also examines human behaviour but more through these aspects.
  • • Option C.
  • • Anthropology:
  • • physical, social
  • • cultural history
  • • man. It also examines human behaviour but more through these aspects.
  • • Option D. Medical sociology: Study of Social and cultural factors in health , health behavior illness and healthcare.
  • • Option D.
  • • Medical sociology:
  • • Social
  • • cultural factors
  • • health
  • • health behavior illness and healthcare.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sociology is the study of human social behavior , including how individuals interact with each other and the patterns of behavior within societies . In the context of public health, sociology is important for understanding how social structures, cultural norms and group dynamics impact health behaviors and outcomes . This field helps to analyze and address various social determinants of health.
  • ➤ Sociology
  • ➤ human social behavior
  • ➤ each other
  • ➤ patterns of behavior
  • ➤ societies
  • ➤ public health, sociology
  • ➤ understanding
  • ➤ social structures, cultural norms
  • ➤ group dynamics
  • ➤ health behaviors
  • ➤ outcomes
  • ➤ analyze
  • ➤ address
  • ➤ social determinants
  • ➤ Ref : Park 26 th ed pg. 760
  • ➤ Ref : Park 26 th ed pg. 760

questions.text: A cultural anthropologist gave a lecture on social behaviors at a medical conference. He emphasized the importance of understanding the various behaviors and beliefs of patients to provide holistic care. One medical resident inquired about behaviors learned through societal interactions and their term. Which of the following best encapsulates behaviors and practices learned socially?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Culture

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Customs: Customs are established patterns of behavior relevant for a particular social setting.
  • • Option A.
  • • Customs:
  • • established
  • • behavior
  • • particular social setting.
  • • Option C. Roles: Roles refer to the specific functions , responsibilities , and tasks that various individuals or groups play in promoting and maintaining the health and well-being of a community.
  • • Option C.
  • • Roles:
  • • specific functions
  • • responsibilities
  • • tasks
  • • promoting
  • • maintaining
  • • health
  • • well-being
  • • community.
  • • Option D. Beliefs: Beliefs are subjective permanent, stable and almost unchangeable views .
  • • Option D.
  • • Beliefs:
  • • Beliefs
  • • subjective permanent, stable
  • • unchangeable views

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Culture is defined as learned behavior which has been socially acquired .
  • ➤ Culture
  • ➤ learned behavior
  • ➤ socially acquired
  • ➤ Ref : Park 26 th ed pg. 762
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Park 26 th ed pg. 762

questions.text: During a Public Health workshop, the discussion centered on the impact of societal factors on health outcomes. A medical resident, intrigued by the conversation, inquired about the specific field that examines the relationship between diseases and social conditions. This area of study focuses on understanding how societal factors like poverty, education and cultural practices can influence the prevalence and spread of diseases. Which term most accurately describes this field of study?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Social Pathology

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Social Stress: The psychological and physiological responses that individuals experience because of their interactions and experiences within social environments.
  • • Option A. Social Stress:
  • • psychological
  • • physiological responses
  • • interactions
  • • experiences
  • • social environments.
  • • Option B. Social Anthropology: Social anthropology is a branch of anthropology that centers on the examination of human societies and cultures . It places significant emphasis on understanding social structures , relationships, customs, beliefs and practices that shape the diverse aspects of human social life.
  • • Option B. Social Anthropology:
  • • centers
  • • examination
  • • human societies
  • • cultures
  • • emphasis
  • • understanding social structures
  • • relationships, customs, beliefs
  • • practices
  • • diverse aspects
  • • human social life.
  • • Option D. Medical Sociology: Medical sociology is a specialized branch of sociology that focuses on the social aspects of health, illness, healthcare systems and the interaction between society and medicine.
  • • Option D. Medical Sociology:
  • • social aspects
  • • health, illness, healthcare
  • • systems
  • • interaction between society
  • • medicine.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Social pathology is the field that specifically investigates the relationship between diseases and social conditions . It examines how social, economic and cultural factors can contribute to the development and spread of diseases within a society . This field helps in understanding the societal determinants of health and illness , exploring how social issues can lead to pathological conditions.
  • ➤ Social pathology
  • ➤ investigates
  • ➤ diseases
  • ➤ social conditions
  • ➤ social, economic
  • ➤ cultural factors
  • ➤ development
  • ➤ spread
  • ➤ diseases
  • ➤ society
  • ➤ helps
  • ➤ societal determinants
  • ➤ health
  • ➤ illness
  • ➤ social issues
  • ➤ pathological conditions.
  • ➤ Ref : Park 26 th ed pg. 762
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Park 26 th ed pg. 762

questions.text: Dr. Umesh is conducting a workshop on health education and promotion. While discussing the components of attitude, he lists several elements. Which of the following is NOT typically considered a component of attitude?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Motivation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Attitude includes three components: (ABC Model of attitudes include Affective, Behavioural and cognitive)
  • • three components: (ABC Model of attitudes include Affective, Behavioural and cognitive)
  • • Option A. A cognitive or knowledge element : The beliefs, thoughts and knowledge an individual holds about the object of their attitude.
  • • Option A.
  • • cognitive or knowledge element
  • • beliefs, thoughts
  • • knowledge
  • • holds
  • • object
  • • attitude.
  • • Option B. An affective or feeling element: The emotional or affective response a person has toward the object of their attitude . It involves the feelings and emotions associated with the subject.
  • • Option B.
  • • affective or feeling element:
  • • emotional or affective
  • • object
  • • their attitude
  • • feelings
  • • emotions
  • • subject.
  • • Option C. Behavioural tendencies: The individual's actions or intentions toward the object of their attitude .
  • • Option C. Behavioural
  • • actions
  • • object
  • • attitude
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Attitude consists of three components : a cognitive element encompassing beliefs and knowledge about the attitude object , an BOLD element involving emotional responses towards it and a behavioral tendency indicating the individual's actions or intentions related to the object.
  • • Attitude
  • • three components
  • • cognitive
  • • beliefs
  • • knowledge
  • • attitude object
  • • emotional responses
  • • it
  • • behavioral tendency
  • • individual's actions
  • • intentions
  • • object.
  • • Ref : Park 26 th ed pg. 766
  • • Ref : Park 26 th ed pg. 766

questions.text: Dr. Priya, a pediatrician at a tertiary care hospital, encounters a 7-year-old boy with developmental delays. To better understand the child's specific disabilities and formulate an appropriate management plan, she wants to use a standard assessment scale. A medical student rotating in the pediatric ward inquires about the tools available for such assessments. Which of the following scales is commonly used to assess specific disabilities in children?
questions.correct_answer: B. Handicap, behavior, and skills schedule (HBS)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Handicap, behavior, and skills schedule (HBS)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Wing’s Comprehensive Handicaps , Behavior and Skills Schedule (HBS) is used in epidemiological studies to assess the detailed scales of specific abilities and disabilities in the child population . Wing’s HBS in not useful for those who are not retarded.
  • • Wing’s Comprehensive Handicaps
  • • Behavior
  • • Skills Schedule
  • • epidemiological studies
  • • specific abilities
  • • disabilities
  • • child population
  • • Wing’s HBS
  • • not
  • • not retarded.
  • • MENTAL HEALTH RATING SCALES IN CHILDREN:
  • • 1. Adaptive Behaviour Scale (AAMR ABS): To evaluate functional and behavioural disorder in children and adolescents with mental retardation , autism and other developmental disabilities.
  • • 1. Adaptive Behaviour Scale (AAMR ABS):
  • • functional
  • • behavioural disorder
  • • children
  • • adolescents
  • • mental retardation
  • • autism
  • • developmental disabilities.
  • • 2. Child Behaviour Checklist (CBCL) Scale: To evaluate pathological behaviours and social competence in children aged 1½ to 18 years .
  • • 2. Child Behaviour Checklist (CBCL) Scale:
  • • pathological behaviours
  • • social competence
  • • children
  • • 1½ to 18 years
  • • 3. Children’s Depression Inventory (CDI) Scale: To evaluate depression in children and adolescents.
  • • 3. Children’s Depression Inventory (CDI) Scale:
  • • depression
  • • children
  • • adolescents.
  • • 4. Children’s Depression Rating Scale (CDRS): To evaluate severity of depression in children.
  • • 4. Children’s Depression Rating Scale (CDRS):
  • • severity
  • • depression
  • • 5. Comprehensive Behaviour Rating Scale for Children (CBRS(C): To assess child’s school functioning .
  • • 5. Comprehensive Behaviour Rating Scale for Children (CBRS(C):
  • • child’s school functioning
  • • 6. Conners’ Rating Scale (CRS): To assess psychopathology and behavioural problems in children and adolescents.
  • • 6. Conners’ Rating Scale (CRS):
  • • psychopathology
  • • behavioural problems
  • • children and adolescents.
  • • 7. Diagnostic Interview Schedule for Children (DIS(C): To diagnose mental disorders in children and adolescents.
  • • 7. Diagnostic Interview Schedule for Children (DIS(C):
  • • mental disorders
  • • children
  • • adolescents.
  • • 8. Revised Children’s Manifest Anxiety Scale (RCMAS): To evaluate anxiety in children.
  • • 8. Revised Children’s Manifest Anxiety Scale (RCMAS):
  • • anxiety
  • • 9. Reynolds Adolescent Depression Scale (RADS) : To screen for and measure depression in adolescents.
  • • 9. Reynolds Adolescent Depression Scale (RADS)
  • • depression
  • • adolescents.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Handicap, Behavior and Skills Schedule (HBS), developed by Lorna Wing, is a comprehensive tool used in epidemiological studies to assess detailed scales of specific abilities and disabilities in children. It is particularly useful for assessing a wide range of disabilities and is not limited to children with cognitive retardation . The HBS provides valuable insights into the child's behavioral and skill-based abilities , aiding in formulating tailored management plans .

  • ➤ Skills Schedule (HBS),
  • ➤ Lorna Wing,
  • ➤ epidemiological studies

questions.text: A social worker was observing various community group dynamics to plan her community interventions better. During a meeting in one of the villages, she noticed that all members strictly followed whatever their leader said, without any discussion or questions. This type of obedience reminded her of her sociology lessons. In which type of social group do members usually follow the orders of the leader without question?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Herd

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Crowd : A group of people come together temporarily , for a short period , motivated by a common interest or curiosity . The crowd lacks internal organization and leadership. When the interest is over , the crowd disperses.
  • • Option A. Crowd
  • • group
  • • people
  • • together temporarily
  • • short period
  • • common interest
  • • curiosity
  • • crowd lacks
  • • internal organization and leadership.
  • • interest is over
  • • crowd disperses.
  • • Option B. Mob: Is essentially a crowd but has a leader who forces the members into action . There may be a symbol in the shape of a flag or slogan . The mob is more emotional than a crowd. It is unstable and without internal organization. When the purpose of the mob is achieved , the group disperses.
  • • Option B. Mob:
  • • crowd
  • • leader
  • • forces
  • • members
  • • action
  • • symbol
  • • flag or slogan
  • • mob
  • • more emotional
  • • unstable
  • • without internal organization.
  • • mob
  • • achieved
  • • group disperses.
  • • Option D. Family: A group of biologically related individuals living together and eating from a common kitchen . Family is the primary unit of all societies . Family is the most powerful example of social cohesion.
  • • Option D. Family:
  • • biologically
  • • individuals living together
  • • eating
  • • common kitchen
  • • Family
  • • primary unit
  • • all societies
  • • Family
  • • powerful example
  • • social cohesion.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Herd : A crowd with a leader , where the members of the group have to follow the orders of the leader without question.
  • ➤ The Herd
  • ➤ crowd with a leader
  • ➤ members
  • ➤ group
  • ➤ orders
  • ➤ leader without question.
  • ➤ Ref: Park 26 th ed pg. 772
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ Park 26 th ed pg. 772

questions.text: In a health economics seminar, participants were discussing the impact of various governmental systems on health infrastructure. One system was highlighted, where both production and wealth are under the control of the state. This system is known as:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Socialist

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Monarchy: This is a form of government ruled by a monarch , such as a king or queen.
  • • Option A. Monarchy:

  • • king or queen.
  • • Option B. Autocracy: This refers to a system of government where one person holds absolute power .

  • • system of government
  • • one person
  • • absolute power
  • • Option C. Oligarchy: This is a form of power structure where a small number of people (usually members of a family group) control a country or organization.
  • • Option C. Oligarchy:
  • • power structure
  • • small number
  • • control
  • • country
  • • organization.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Types of system:
  • ➤ Types of system:
  • ➤ Democracy: This is the government of the people, by the people and for the people. Autocracy: The ruler is absolute in his power . Monarchy: The head of the State is a monarch. Socialistic: The production and wealth are owned and controlled by the State. Oligarchy: The country is ruled by a family group .

questions.text: All of the following are characteristics of Joint family, except?

options.label: A
options.text: Marital relations enjoy primacy over familial relations

options.label: B
options.text: All the authority is vested in the senior male member of the family

options.label: C
options.text: All the men are related by blood

options.label: D
options.text: All the incomes are held together and expenditures met together.

questions.correct_answer: A. Marital relations enjoy primacy over familial relations
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Marital relations enjoy primacy over familial relations.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The main characteristics of a typical joint family are -
  • • main characteristics
  • • typical joint family
  • • It consists of several married couples and their children who live together in the same household . All the men are related by blood and the women of the household are their wives , unmarried girls and widows of the family kinsmen . All the property is held in common . There is a common family purse to which all the family income goes and from which all the expenditures are met . All the authority is vested in the senior male member of the family. He is the most dominant member and controls the internal and external affairs of the family . The senior female member by virtue of her being the wife of the male head shares his power so far as the women of the family are concerned . Familial relations enjoy primacy over marital relations.
  • • It consists of several married couples and their children who live together in the same household . All the men are related by blood and the women of the household are their wives , unmarried girls and widows of the family kinsmen .
  • • several married couples
  • • their children
  • • together
  • • same household
  • • men
  • • related
  • • blood
  • • women
  • • household
  • • their wives
  • • unmarried girls
  • • widows
  • • family kinsmen
  • • All the property is held in common . There is a common family purse to which all the family income goes and from which all the expenditures are met .
  • • property
  • • common
  • • common family
  • • family income goes
  • • from
  • • expenditures
  • • met
  • • All the authority is vested in the senior male member of the family. He is the most dominant member and controls the internal and external affairs of the family . The senior female member by virtue of her being the wife of the male head shares his power so far as the women of the family are concerned .
  • • authority
  • • vested
  • • senior male member
  • • most dominant member
  • • controls
  • • internal
  • • external affairs
  • • family
  • • senior female member
  • • virtue
  • • wife
  • • male head
  • • his power
  • • women
  • • family
  • • concerned
  • • Familial relations enjoy primacy over marital relations.
  • • Familial
  • • enjoy
  • • primacy
  • • marital relations.
  • • Other Types of Family -
  • • Nuclear Family (Elementary/Unitary Family): Consists of a married couple and their children while they are still regarded as dependents. Joint Family: Consists of no. of married couples and their children who live together in the same household. 3-Generation Family: Consists of a household with representatives of three generations. Complex Family: Is a generic term for any family structure involving more than two adults ; term can refer to any extended family or to a polygamy of any type. Communal Family: Is a family where all of its members are playing a part in its management . This is a good example of ‘ division of labour’ , an important function of a family. New Family: A family of less than 10 years duration and consists of parents and children . It is a variant of nuclear (elementary/unitary) family . This concept is important in view of studies related to family planning.
  • • Nuclear Family (Elementary/Unitary Family): Consists of a married couple and their children while they are still regarded as dependents.
  • • Nuclear Family (Elementary/Unitary Family):

  • • their children
  • • still regarded
  • • dependents.

  • • Joint Family:

  • • together
  • • same household.
  • • 3-Generation Family: Consists of a household with representatives of three generations.
  • • 3-Generation Family:
  • • household
  • • representatives
  • • three generations.
  • • Complex Family: Is a generic term for any family structure involving more than two adults ; term can refer to any extended family or to a polygamy of any type.

  • • more

  • • Communal Family:
  • • family
  • • its members
  • • part
  • • its management

  • • New Family: A family of less than 10 years duration and consists of parents and children . It is a variant of nuclear (elementary/unitary) family . This concept is important in view of studies related to family planning.
  • • New Family: A family

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A joint family comprises multiple married couples and their children living together, with male members related by blood and females as wives, daughters, sisters and widows . Property and finances are communal, authority rests with the eldest male , and family relations take precedence over marital ones .

questions.text: A nuclear family, a fundamental unit in societal structures, is defined by its composition. What constitutes a nuclear family?

options.label: B
options.text: Husband, wife and their dependent children

options.label: D
options.text: Son, Husband, wife and their father.

questions.correct_answer: B. Husband, wife and their dependent children
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Husband, wife and their dependent children

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The nuclear or elementary family (Unitary Family) consists of the married couple and their children while they are still regarded as dependents.
  • • nuclear or elementary family (Unitary Family)
  • • married couple
  • • their children
  • • still regarded
  • • dependents.
  • • Other types of family:
  • • Other types of family:
  • • Joint Family - Consists of no. of married couples and their children who live together in the same household . All males are related by blood while females are wives, daughters, sisters and widows . Property is held in common; there is a common family purse to which all the family income goes and from which all the expenditures are met . All authority is vested in the senior male member of the family. Familial relations enjoy primacy over marital relations.
  • • Joint Family
  • • no. of married couples
  • • their children
  • • same household
  • • All males
  • • related by blood
  • • females

  • • Familial relations
  • • enjoy
  • • marital relations.
  • • New Family: A family of less than 10 years duration and consists of parents and children . It is a variant of the nuclear (elementary/unitary) family.
  • • New Family:
  • • less than 10 years duration
  • • parents
  • • children
  • • variant
  • • nuclear
  • • family.
  • • 3-Generation Family: Consists of a household with representatives of three generations.
  • • 3-Generation Family:
  • • household with representatives
  • • three generations.
  • • Complex Family : This is a generic term for any family structure involving more than two adults ; the term can refer to any extended family or polygamy of any type.
  • • Complex Family
  • • generic term
  • • family structure
  • • more
  • • two adults
  • • extended family
  • • polygamy
  • • Conjugal Family : Is a nuclear family of adult partners and their children (by birth or adoption ) where the family relationship is principally focused inwardly and ties to extended kin are voluntary and based on emotional bonds , rather than strict duties and obligations; most common form is nuclear family
  • • Conjugal Family
  • • nuclear family
  • • adult partners
  • • their children
  • • birth
  • • adoption
  • • family relationship
  • • inwardly

  • • family
  • • all
  • • its members
  • • playing
  • • its management (Division of Labour).
  • • Problem Family: A family that lags behind the rest of the community ; underlying factors in most problem families are those of personality , relationships , backwardness , poverty, illness, mental and social instability , character defects, and marital disharmony . Standards of life are generally far below the accepted minimum . Parents are unable to meet the physical and emotional needs of children. Home life is utterly unsatisfactory.

This family structure is characterized by its immediate family members only, distinguishing it from extended or joint family systems that include additional relatives such as grandparents, aunts, uncles and cousins.

questions.text: During an internship, a medical student is placed in a community health setting to understand the social determinants of health. On her first day, her mentor asked her to interact with the community members to gather insights about their daily lives. As she prepares, she reflects on the term "society" to better understand and approach her interactions. What does the term "society" primarily refer to?

options.label: A
options.text: A group of people bound with social norms and values.

options.label: B
options.text: A group of people with organized system of social relationship

options.label: C
options.text: Group with Organized complex pattern of behavior

options.label: D
options.text: An association patterned the norms of interaction

questions.correct_answer: B. A group of people with organized system of social relationship
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. A group of people with organized system of social relationships

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Society refers to a group of individuals who have established an organized system of social relationships and follow a specific way of life. This system is characterized by interconnectedness and interdependence among its members, defining how they interact with each other and organize their collective existence . It's not just about people living in proximity , but about the structure and quality of their relationships .
  • • Society
  • • group of individuals
  • • organized system
  • • social relationships
  • • specific way
  • • life.
  • • interconnectedness
  • • interdependence
  • • interact with each other
  • • collective existence
  • • not
  • • living
  • • proximity
  • • structure
  • • quality
  • • relationships
  • • Other important terms:
  • • Other important terms:
  • • Community - A social group determined by geographical boundaries and/or common values or interests.
  • • Community
  • • geographical boundaries
  • • common values
  • • interests.
  • • Social structure - Patterns of inter-relationships between persons in a society.
  • • Social structure
  • • Patterns
  • • inter-relationships between
  • • society.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Society is a group of individuals who have organized themselves and follow a way of life . The outstanding feature of society is a System , a system of relationships between individuals.
  • ➤ Society
  • ➤ group
  • ➤ organized themselves
  • ➤ way of life
  • ➤ System
  • ➤ relationships between individuals.
  • ➤ Ref : Park 26 th ed, pg 761.
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Park 26 th ed, pg 761.

questions.text: Dr. Ramesh, a community medicine specialist, is giving a lecture on understanding the determinants of health to a group of medical students. During the session, he emphasized the importance of understanding human history, including the physical, social, and cultural evolution of humans, as it often shapes many health behaviors and practices observed in different communities. A curious medical student asks about the specific term that refers to this study. Which of the following terms best describes the study of the physical, social and cultural history of humans?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Anthropology

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Sociology: Sociology is the scientific study of human society, social interactions , and the patterns of behavior that emerge from these interactions . It is a discipline that examines the structure, development and functioning of human societies, as well as the individuals and groups that constitute them.
  • • Option A. Sociology:
  • • study
  • • human society, social
  • • interactions
  • • patterns of behavior
  • • interactions
  • • discipline
  • • examines
  • • structure, development
  • • functioning
  • • individuals
  • • groups
  • • Option B. Social Structure: The various elements of social structure such as social institutions (e.g., family, education, religion, government), social hierarchies (e.g., social class, race, gender), and social norms (e.g., customs, values, rules).
  • • Option B. Social Structure:
  • • elements
  • • social structure
  • • social institutions
  • • hierarchies
  • • social norms
  • • Option C. Medical Sociology: Medical sociology is a specialized branch of sociology that focuses on the social aspects of health, illness, healthcare systems and the interaction between society and medicine.
  • • Option C. Medical Sociology:
  • • specialized branch
  • • health, illness, healthcare
  • • systems
  • • interaction
  • • society and medicine.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The role of social anthropology in health sciences. It offers a comprehensive view of how human history, including physical, social and cultural evolution, shapes health behaviors and practices in different communities, thus aiding medical professionals in developing culturally sensitive health interventions and understanding the diverse health needs of various populations.
  • ➤ social anthropology
  • ➤ physical, social
  • ➤ cultural evolution,
  • ➤ health behaviors
  • ➤ practices
  • ➤ medical professionals
  • ➤ culturally sensitive health interventions
  • ➤ diverse health
  • ➤ various populations.
  • ➤ Ref : Park 26 th ed, pg 760.
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Park 26 th ed, pg 760.

questions.text: In a lecture on cultural influences in healthcare, a discussion arises about acculturation and its relevance in understanding patient behavior and health practices. The lecturer asks the students to identify what acculturation is most closely associated with.Which of the following options best describes the primary association of acculturation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Cultural contact

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Acculturation means “ culture contact ”. When there is contact between two people with different types of culture , there is diffusion of culture both ways.
  • • Acculturation
  • • culture contact
  • • contact between
  • • different types
  • • culture
  • • diffusion
  • • culture both ways.
  • • Various Ways by which culture contact :
  • • culture contact
  • • Trade and commerce Industrialization Propagation of religion Education Conquest.
  • • Trade and commerce
  • • Industrialization
  • • Propagation of religion
  • • Education
  • • Conquest.
  • • Sociology is the study of individuals as well as groups in a society. It can be viewed as from 2 angles - Study of relationships between human beings and the study of human behaviour .
  • • Sociology
  • • individuals
  • • groups
  • • 2 angles
  • • relationships
  • • human beings
  • • human behaviour
  • • Socialisation is the process by which an individual gradually acquires culture and becomes member of a social group.
  • • Socialisation
  • • individual gradually acquires
  • • culture
  • • member
  • • social group.
  • • Culture is the learned behaviour that is socially acquired.
  • • Culture
  • • learned behaviour
  • • socially acquired.
  • • Custom is the established patterns of behaviour that can be objectively verified within a particular social setting . Folkways is the Right ways of doing things in less vital areas of human conduct and Mores are the more stringent customs.
  • • Custom
  • • patterns of behaviour
  • • particular social setting
  • • Folkways
  • • Right ways
  • • less vital
  • • human conduct
  • • Mores
  • • more stringent customs.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acculturation is primarily associated with cultural contact . It occurs when individuals or groups from different cultural backgrounds come into direct and sustained contact with each other , leading to the exchange and modification of cultural practices, beliefs and values . This process can significantly impact health behaviors, attitudes and practices , making it a key consideration in culturally sensitive healthcare .
  • ➤ Acculturation
  • ➤ cultural contact
  • ➤ different cultural backgrounds
  • ➤ direct
  • ➤ sustained contact
  • ➤ each other
  • ➤ exchange
  • ➤ modification of cultural practices, beliefs and values
  • ➤ health behaviors, attitudes and practices
  • ➤ culturally sensitive healthcare
  • ➤ Ref : Park 26 th ed, pg 760.
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Park 26 th ed, pg 760.

questions.text: During his first few weeks in medical school, Rajan, a student who grew up in an urban environment, found himself intrigued by the behaviors, values, and practices of his classmates who hailed from various cultural backgrounds. He observed them adopting specific behaviors and norms typical of the medical community. This experience made Rajan realize the significance of a specific process by which individuals integrate into a new cultural or social setting. What is this process called?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Socialization

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Acculturation: It means cultural contact . Mixing of two different cultures creates a new one is called Acculturation . It occurs by means of Marriage, Conquest etc.
  • • Option A. Acculturation:
  • • cultural contact
  • • two different cultures
  • • Acculturation
  • • Marriage, Conquest
  • • Option C. Custom: Established patterns of behavior relevant to a particular social setting .
  • • Option C. Custom:
  • • patterns
  • • behavior
  • • particular social setting
  • • Option D. Socialism: This is an economic doctrine that favors the use of property and resources of the country for public welfare; it is a system of production and distribution based on social ownership.
  • • Option D.
  • • Socialism:
  • • economic doctrine
  • • favors
  • • property
  • • resources
  • • country
  • • public welfare;
  • • production
  • • distribution
  • • social ownership.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Socialization is the process by which individuals learn and internalize the behaviors , values, norms and roles of a particular culture or social group . It helps individuals integrate into their new cultural or social setting and acquire the knowledge and skills necessary to function effectively within that environment.
  • ➤ Socialization
  • ➤ individuals learn
  • ➤ internalize
  • ➤ behaviors
  • ➤ values, norms
  • ➤ culture
  • ➤ social group
  • ➤ integrate
  • ➤ new cultural
  • ➤ social setting
  • ➤ acquire
  • ➤ knowledge
  • ➤ skills necessary
  • ➤ effectively
  • ➤ environment.
  • ➤ Ref : Park 26 th ed, pg 761
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Park 26 th ed, pg 761

questions.text: Dr. Sameer is conducting a health campaign in a rural village to promote the importance of childhood vaccination. During his interactions, he encounters a group of parents who express a temporary concern about vaccine side effects due to recent news coverage, even though they had been previously favorable towards vaccines. This temporary view held by the parents is best termed as?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Opinion

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Belief: Permanent, subjective, stable and almost unchangeable views.
  • • Option A. Belief:
  • • Permanent, subjective, stable
  • • unchangeable views.
  • • Option C. Emotion: Strong feelings that motivate human behavior . The most common emotion is Fear.
  • • Option C. Emotion:
  • • Strong feelings
  • • motivate human behavior
  • • most
  • • Fear.
  • • Option D. Attitude: More or less permanent ways of behavior based on objective organization of beliefs on object/person/situation.
  • • Option D. Attitude:
  • • More or less permanent
  • • objective organization
  • • beliefs on object/person/situation.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Opinion refers to an individual's view or judgment on a particular matter, which can be influenced by various factors , including new information or experiences.
  • ➤ Opinion
  • ➤ individual's view
  • ➤ judgment
  • ➤ particular matter,
  • ➤ influenced
  • ➤ various factors
  • ➤ new information
  • ➤ experiences.
  • ➤ Ref : Park 26 th ed, pg. 766
  • ➤ Ref : Park 26 th ed, pg. 766

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is forcibly separated from his father due to a court-ordered custody decision. This situation exemplifies which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Broken family

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Problem families: Problem families are those which lag behind the rest of the community. In these families, the standards of life are generally far below the accepted minimum and parents are unable to meet the physical and emotional needs of their children . Family lags in progress behind the rest of the community due to relationships problems , poverty and illnesses .
  • • Option A.
  • • Problem families:
  • • lag behind
  • • rest
  • • standards
  • • life
  • • far below
  • • minimum
  • • parents
  • • unable
  • • physical and emotional
  • • their children
  • • Family lags
  • • behind
  • • relationships problems
  • • poverty
  • • illnesses
  • • Option B. Dysfunctional Family : Is a family in which conflict, misbehavior and even abuse on the part of individual members of the family occur continually , leading other members to accommodate such actions .
  • • Option B.
  • • Dysfunctional Family
  • • which conflict, misbehavior
  • • abuse
  • • individual members
  • • family
  • • continually
  • • other members
  • • accommodate
  • • actions
  • • Option D: New Family is a family where marriage duration is less than 10 years . They are targeted for contraceptive services by the RCH program.
  • • Option D: New Family
  • • less than 10 years
  • • RCH program.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Broken family , which is characterized by the dissolution of the marital relationship between the parents or caregivers . The term " broken family " is commonly used in the context of family dynamics and describes a family structure where the parents are no longer together.

  • ➤ dissolution
  • ➤ marital relationship between

  • ➤ parents

  • ➤ Ref : Park 26 th ed, pg. 775

questions.text: During a public health seminar, a speaker is discussing Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs and how it plays a role in understanding human motivations and behavior. Which of the following represents the correct sequence, starting from the most basic needs at the bottom to the highest needs at the top?

options.label: A
options.text: Physiological needs, Self-actualization needs, esteem needs, Safety needs, and social needs

options.label: B
options.text: Physiological needs, social needs, Safety needs, Self-actualization needs, Esteem needs

options.label: C
options.text: Physiological needs, Safety needs, social needs, Esteem needs, Self-actualization needs

options.label: D
options.text: Physiological needs, Esteem needs, social needs, Self-actualization needs, Safety needs.

questions.correct_answer: C. Physiological needs, Safety needs, social needs, Esteem needs, Self-actualization needs
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Physiological needs, Safety needs, social needs, Esteem needs, Self-actualization needs

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs is a theory in psychology proposed by Abraham Maslow in his 1943 paper " A Theory of Human Motivation ." It is often depicted as a pyramid with the most fundamental levels of needs at the bottom and the need for self-actualization at the top . The correct sequence from the bottom to the top is:
  • • Maslow's Hierarchy
  • • psychology proposed
  • • Abraham Maslow
  • • 1943 paper
  • • A Theory of Human Motivation
  • • pyramid
  • • fundamental levels
  • • needs
  • • bottom
  • • self-actualization
  • • top
  • • correct
  • • bottom
  • • top

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of Maslow's Hierarchy of Need Model is - Physiological needs, Safety needs, Social needs, Esteem needs, Self-actualization needs.

  • ➤ : IAPSM textbook, 1 st ed, pg. 986

questions.text: Dr. Shashi is a public health officer working in an urban health center in India. He is assessing the socioeconomic status of families in his area to allocate resources appropriately. He decided to use the Modified Kuppuswamy socioeconomic scale for his assessment. A junior intern accompanying him asks about the components considered in the Modified Kuppuswamy scale. Which of the following is NOT a component of the Modified Kuppuswamy socioeconomic scale?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Per capita Income

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Modified Kuppuswami Scale is widely used to assess the socioeconomic status of individuals or families in India. It takes into account three key components to determine socioeconomic status:
  • • Modified Kuppuswami Scale
  • • socioeconomic status
  • • individuals
  • • families
  • • three
  • • components
  • • socioeconomic status:
  • • Education: The level of education attained by the head of the household is considered as a proxy for the overall educational status of the family. Occupation: The occupation of the head of the household is used to assess the economic status of the family . Income: The total monthly family income is another important indicator of socioeconomic status.
  • • Education: The level of education attained by the head of the household is considered as a proxy for the overall educational status of the family.
  • • Education:
  • • head
  • • household
  • • a proxy
  • • overall educational
  • • family.
  • • Occupation: The occupation of the head of the household is used to assess the economic status of the family .
  • • Occupation:
  • • head
  • • household
  • • economic status
  • • .
  • • Income: The total monthly family income is another important indicator of socioeconomic status.
  • • Income:
  • • total monthly family income
  • • socioeconomic status.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Modified Kuppuswami Scale evaluates socioeconomic status in India using three criteria: education and occupation of the household head , and total family income .
  • ➤ Modified Kuppuswami Scale
  • ➤ socioeconomic status
  • ➤ education
  • ➤ occupation
  • ➤ household head
  • ➤ total family income
  • ➤ Ref : Park 26 th ed, pg 780
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Park 26 th ed, pg 780

questions.text: Which of the following correctly matches the socioeconomic status (SES) scale to its appropriate application in rural or urban areas in India?
questions.correct_answer: C. Udai Pareek Scale – Rural areas
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Udai Pareek Scale – Rural areas

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Udai Pareek Scale is specifically designed to assess socioeconomic status in rural settings. It includes indicators such as landholding, caste, housing, and type of family, which are more relevant in rural India.
  • • Udai Pareek Scale
  • • Modified Kuppuswamy Scale is used for urban populations and considers education, occupation, and income as primary indicators.
  • • Modified Kuppuswamy Scale
  • • BG Prasad Scale (and its modified versions) is applicable to rural populations and is primarily used in community-based health research, especially where income is the main determinant.
  • • BG Prasad Scale (and its modified versions)
  • • Bhardwaj scale is used to evaluate socioeconomic status of students
  • • Bhardwaj scale

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Urban SES scales include Modified Kuppuswamy Scale, Kulshreshtha Scale, Srivastava Scale and Jalota Scale. Rural SES scales include Udai Pareek Scale, Modified B. G. Prasad Scale, Radhukar Scale and Shirpurkar Scale. International SES scales include Hollingshead (Occupation based) Scale and Henderson Scale. Students SES scales include Bhardwaj scale.
  • ➤ Urban SES scales
  • ➤ Rural SES scales
  • ➤ International SES scales
  • ➤ Students SES scales
  • ➤ Ref. Park 26 th ed., pg 780
  • ➤ Ref. Park 26 th ed., pg 780

questions.text: A junior resident is assessing the economic well-being of a rural area as part of her postgraduate project. She recalls the criteria used to define the poverty line for rural areas in terms of purchasing capacity. According to this criterion, what is the threshold for calorie intake per person per day below which an individual in a rural area is considered below the poverty line?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 2400

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Poverty threshold (poverty line): Is the minimum level of income deemed necessary to achieve an adequate standard of living.
  • • Poverty threshold (poverty line):
  • • minimum level
  • • income
  • • achieve
  • • adequate standard
  • • living.
  • • Rural area - The poverty line is the inability to buy adequate food calories equivalent to 2400 per day/head.
  • • Rural area -
  • • poverty line
  • • inability
  • • buy adequate food calories
  • • 2400 per day/head.
  • • Urban area - Inability to buy adequate food calories equivalent to 2100 per day/head.
  • • Urban area
  • • Inability
  • • buy adequate food calories

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary metric often referenced when assessing the standard of living for a population?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Per capita income

questions.text: A public health researcher is delivering a presentation on global nutrition and hunger issues to a group of medical students. He challenges the students to recall the components of the Global Hunger Index (GHI). While discussing the various indicators, a student lists four potential components. Which of the following indicators is NOT part of the Global Hunger Index?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Longevity

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Global Hunger Index (GHI) is an annual report that measures and tracks hunger and malnutrition around the world.
  • • Global Hunger Index (GHI)
  • • measures
  • • tracks hunger
  • • malnutrition
  • • world.
  • • To capture the multidimensional nature of hunger, GHI scores are based on the following indicators:
  • • multidimensional
  • • hunger,
  • • GHI
  • • Calculation -
  • • Proportion of Undernourished population (PNU) Wasting and Stunting in Children ( Underweight ) (CUW) Under-five mortality (U5M)
  • • Proportion of Undernourished population (PNU)
  • • Undernourished population
  • • Wasting and Stunting in Children ( Underweight ) (CUW)
  • • Wasting
  • • Stunting
  • • Underweight
  • • Under-five mortality (U5M)
  • • Under-five mortality
  • • GHI Classification and Interpretation:
  • • The International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI) calculates GHI scores each year to assess progress , or the lack there of, in combating hunger .
  • • International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI)
  • • GHI scores
  • • year
  • • assess progress
  • • lack
  • • combating hunger
  • • India, Global Hunger Index GHI 2024: Score 27.3, Serious level of hunger (Rank 105th out of the 127 countries)
  • • India, Global Hunger Index GHI 2024: Score 27.3, Serious level of hunger (Rank 105th out of the 127 countries)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Global Hunger Index (GHI) is a tool designed to comprehensively measure and track hunger at the global, regional and country levels . It is calculated (2016) with the help of the following indicators - Child (Under 5 age) Undernourishment , Wasting (Acute undernutrition), Stunting (Chronic undernutrition) and mortality.
  • ➤ Global Hunger Index (GHI)
  • ➤ comprehensively measure
  • ➤ track hunger
  • ➤ the global, regional and country levels
  • ➤ Child (Under 5 age)
  • ➤ Undernourishment
  • ➤ Wasting (Acute undernutrition), Stunting (Chronic undernutrition)
  • ➤ mortality.
  • ➤ Ref : Park 26 th ed pg 792.
  • ➤ Ref : Park 26 th ed pg 792.

questions.text: A Nutritional Expert conducted a health workshop in a semi-urban school. While discussing nutrition, she highlighted that many children may consume adequate calories but still suffer from nutritional deficiencies, which aren't immediately apparent. This type of nutritional insufficiency is known as "hidden hunger." Which of the following is most likely responsible for hidden hunger?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Micronutrients

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Hidden hunger (micronutrient deficiency) is a form of undernutrition that occurs when intake and absorption of vitamins and minerals (such as zinc, iodine, and iron ) are too low to sustain good health and development .
  • • Hidden hunger (micronutrient deficiency)
  • • undernutrition
  • • intake and absorption
  • • vitamins and minerals
  • • zinc, iodine, and iron
  • • too low
  • • good health
  • • development

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hidden Hunger is micronutrient deficiency.
  • ➤ Hidden Hunger
  • ➤ micronutrient deficiency.
  • ➤ Ref : Park 26 th ed pg. 792.
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Park 26 th ed pg. 792.

questions.text: A public health researcher is collecting data in a rural community to analyze the determinants affecting the standard of living. During a community gathering, she highlights several factors and asks community members to identify which factor is least likely to directly impact the standard of living. Which of the following is NOT directly associated with determining the standard of living in a country?
questions.correct_answer: C. Life expectancy of the population
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Life expectancy of the population

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The standard of living in a country depends upon :

  • • The total amount of goods and services a country can produce.
  • • goods and services

  • • population
  • • The level of education
  • • level
  • • education
  • • General price level and
  • • General price level
  • • The distribution of national income.
  • • distribution
  • • national income.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Standard of Living : Refers to the usual scale of our expenditure, goods we consume and services we enjoy . As per WHO , the Standard of living includes Income and Occupation , Standards of housing, sanitation and nutrition , Level of provision of health, education , recreational and other services.
